title: Joshua Cleansed and Commissioned
shortSummary: Zechariah chapter 3 presents a vision of Joshua the high priest standing before the angel of the LORD, accused by Satan but defended and cleansed by God. This chapter highlights God's forgiveness, the removal of sin, and the promise of the coming Messiah, referred to as the Branch. It underscores the themes of divine justice, mercy, and restoration for God's people.
timeline: c. 520 BC - Post-exilic period during the rebuilding of the temple in Jerusalem

keyCharacters.name: Joshua the High Priest
keyCharacters.description: The high priest representing Israel, who stands accused but is cleansed and restored by God in this vision.

keyCharacters.name: Satan
keyCharacters.description: The adversary who stands at Joshua's right hand to accuse and resist him before God.

keyCharacters.name: Angel of the LORD
keyCharacters.description: The divine messenger who appears with Joshua and speaks God's words of rebuke against Satan and encouragement to Joshua.

keyCharacters.name: The Branch
keyCharacters.description: A prophetic title for the coming Messiah, whom God promises to bring forth as a servant and redeemer.

definitions.definition: Symbolic clothing representing sin and impurity, which Joshua wore before being cleansed.
A ceremonial headpiece worn by the high priest, symbolizing his office and authority.
A Messianic title referring to the promised righteous servant and king who would restore Israel.
A symbolic number representing God's perfect knowledge and omniscience, engraved on the stone.

outline.heading: Joshua Accused and Rebuked
outline.description: Joshua stands before the angel of the LORD while Satan accuses him; God rebukes Satan, affirming Joshua as a 'brand plucked out of the fire,' symbolizing God's mercy in saving him.

outline.heading: Cleansing of Joshua
outline.description: Joshua is clothed in filthy garments representing sin; God commands their removal and clothes him in clean garments with a fair mitre, signifying forgiveness and restoration to priestly office.

outline.heading: Godâ€™s Charge and Promise to Joshua
outline.description: The angel of the LORD instructs Joshua to walk in God's ways and keep His charge, promising authority to judge God's house and fellowship with heavenly beings.

outline.heading: The Coming Branch and Removal of Iniquity
outline.description: God announces the coming of His servant, the Branch, and the laying of a stone with seven eyes, symbolizing divine perfection and the removal of iniquity from the land in a single day.

outline.heading: Promise of Peaceful Fellowship
outline.description: A future day is promised when people will live in peace, calling each other under the vine and fig tree, a symbol of security and prosperity.

application: Recognize that God can remove our sins and clothe us with righteousness through His mercy and grace.
Commit to walking in God's ways and obeying His commands as a response to His forgiveness and calling.
Trust in the promised coming of Christ, the Branch, who will bring ultimate restoration and peace.
Live in the hope of God's future kingdom where peace and fellowship will abound among His people.

keyVerses.text: And the LORD said unto Satan, The LORD rebuke thee, O Satan; even the LORD that hath chosen Jerusalem rebuke thee: is not this a brand plucked out of the fire?
keyVerses.significance: This verse shows God's sovereign defense of His people and His power to save sinners from destruction.

keyVerses.text: And he answered and spake unto those that stood before him, saying, Take away the filthy garments from him. And unto him he said, Behold, I have caused thine iniquity to pass from thee, and I will clothe thee with change of raiment.
keyVerses.significance: It illustrates God's forgiveness, cleansing from sin, and the restoration of the believer to a position of honor.

keyVerses.text: Hear now, O Joshua the high priest, thou, and thy fellows that sit before thee: for they are men wondered at: for, behold, I will bring forth my servant the BRANCH.
keyVerses.significance: This verse prophesies the coming Messiah, the Branch, who will bring salvation and hope to God's people.

keyVerses.text: In that day, saith the LORD of hosts, shall ye call every man his neighbour under the vine and under the fig tree.
keyVerses.significance: It promises a future time of peace, safety, and joyful fellowship among God's people.
